document.masterDocTitle: New species and record of Pseudonereis (Annelida, Polychaeta, Nereididae) from Taiwan

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: New species and record of Pseudonereis (Annelida, Polychaeta, Nereididae) from Taiwan

subSubSection.paragraph: Figs 1A–F , 2A–F , 3A–D , 4A–H

Material examined.
Holotype ( NMNS 8383-1 ), atoke: Jihuei ( 23°6.97'N 121°24.31'E ), Taitung County , Taiwan , rocky intertidal habitats,
9 October 2010
.
Paratypes : 5 specimens ( NMNS 8383-2 – 6 ), collection locality, habitat and date information same as holotype
;
2 specimens ( NMNS 8383-7 – 8 ), collection locality and habitat information same as holotype ,
27 March 2014
;
2 specimens ( NMNS 8383-9 – 10 ), collection locality and habitat information same as holotype ,
28 March 2014
;
5 specimens ( NMNS 8383-11 – 15 ), collection locality and habitat information same as holotype ,
27 September 2014
;
1 specimen ( NMNS 8383-16 ), collection locality and habitat information same as holotype ,
29 April 2017
. Epitoke:
7 specimens ( NMNS 8383-17 – 23 ), collection locality and habitat information same as holotype ,
8–9 October 2010
;
1 specimen ( NMNS 8383-24 ), collection locality and habitat informa- tion same as holotype ,
27 September 2014
.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 1.
Pseudonereis jihueiensis
n. sp.
; A, paratype (NMNS 8383-16); B, holotype (NMNS 8383-1); C, paratype (NMNS 8383-18); D, paratype (NMNS 8383-5); E–F, paratype (NMNS 8383-11): A–C, anterior body, dorsal view; D, jaws; E, parag- naths of the pharynx, dorsal view; F, paragnaths of the pharynx, frontal view. Scale: A–C, 1.0 mm; D–F, 0.5 mm.

FIGURE 2.
Pseudonereis jihueiensis
n. sp.
; holotype (NMNS 8383-1): A, left parapodium, anterior view, chaetiger 10; B, left parapodium, posterior view, chaetiger 10; C, left parapodium, chaetiger 30; D, left parapodium, chaetiger 43; E, left parapo- dium, chaetiger 64; F, left parapodium, chaetiger 74. Abbreviation: DC, dorsal cirrus; NeIA, neuroacicular inferior lobe; NePL, neuropodial postchaetal lobe; NeSA, neuroacicular superior acicular lobe; NeVL, neuropodial ventral ligule; NoDL, notopodial dorsal ligule; NoVL, notopodial ventral ligule; VC, ventral cirrus. Scale: A–F, 0.5 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph: Pygidium crenulated; anal cirri cirriform, as long as last 7 chaetigers.

Variation. Length ratio of apodous anterior segment to chaetiger 1 ranged from 1.1–1.7 (n= 15); longest ten- tacular cirrus reached chaetiger 3–5 (n= 13). Paragnath numbers in Area II ranged 20–39 (left) and 21–38 (right) in 4–5 rows (n= 14), Area III 49–90 in 4–6 rows (n=14), Area IV 62–112 (left) and 61–106 (right) in 5–6 rows (n= 14), Area VII–VIII 17–22 (n=15), respectively. Length of anal cirri ranged from as long as last 4 to 7 chaetigers (n= 5).

Epitoke: Description based on specimen NMNS 8383-18, male, complete, body length 63.5 mm with 106 chaetigers; beige in alcohol ( Fig. 1C ). Body divided into two regions: 1) pre-natatory region from chaetiger 1 to 11; 2) natatory region from chaetiger 12 to end of body.
Notopodial and neuropodial chaetae same as atokous stage, paddle-like natatory chaetae absent throughout.
Pygidium crenulated; anal cirri cirriform, as long as last 7 chaetigers.

Variation. Length ratio of apodous anterior segment to chaetiger 1 ranged 1.4–1.6 (n= 7); longest tentacular cirrus reached chaetiger 4–6 (n= 7). Paragnath numbers in Area I ranged 0–4, Area II 18–37 (left) and 23–38 (right) in 4–5 rows (n= 7), Area III 53–92 in 4–5 rows (n= 7), Area IV 70–91 (left) and 67–90 (right) in 5 rows (n= 7), Area VII–VIII 17–22 (n= 7), respectively. Number of chaetigers in pre-natatory region ranged 14–17 chaetigers (n= 7), and beginning chaetiger of natatory region ranged from chaetiger 15 to 18 (n= 7). Length of anal cirri ranged from as long as last 4 to 7 chaetigers (n= 5).
Etymology. The name is derived from the name of village, Jihuei, where the worms were collected.

Type locality.
Jihuei , Taitung County , Taiwan
.
Distribution. Only known from the type locality.

Remarks. Of the 20 known species of the genus, only
P . formosa Kinberg, 1865
,
P . kihawensis
n. sp.
, and
P . podocirra (Schmarda, 1861)
have no heterogomph spinigers in the subacicular fascicle of the neuropodia as in
P . jihueiensis
n. sp.
( Conde-Vela 2018: 270 ;
Kara et al . 2018: 1289
; Table 1 ). However,
P . jihueiensis
n. sp.
can be distinguished from
P . formosa
by having: 1) edentate jaws (versus 5–7 lateral teeth on the cutting edge of the jaws); 2) smaller ratio of dorsal cirrus to dorsal ligule on anterior and mid-body chaetigers (1.3 and 1.1 versus 2.0 and 1.5, respectively) and greater ratio of dorsal cirrus to dorsal ligule on posterior chaetigers (0.6 versus 0.4); 3) tip of dorsal ligule becoming small pennant-like lobe on mid-body chaetigers (versus rounded); 4) oblong dorsal ligules on posterior chaetigers (versus pear-shaped) ( Bakken 2007: 157–158 , fig. 7A–E; Conde-Vela 2018: 270 ; Figs 1C–D , 2A–F , Table 1 ).
Pseudonereis jihueiensis
n. sp.
differs from
P . podocirra
by having: 1) edentate jaws (versus 6 lateral teeth on the cutting edge of the jaws); 2) paragnaths in Area IV distributed in 5–7 rows (versus 4 rows); 3) shield-shaped bars in Area VI (versus bar+cone); 4) fewer number of paragnaths in Area VII–VIII (17–22 versus 40) and two rows of paragnaths distributed in a narrow band (versus 2–4 rows in a broad band); 5) one pa- ragnath on each furrow and ridge regions in Area VII–VIII (versus 2–3 in Area VIII); and 6) greater dorsal cirrus to dorsal ligule ratio on posterior chaetigers (0.6 versus 0.3) (
Kara et al . 2018: 1287–1289
, figs 3G–I, 4A–C, table 3; Figs 1C–D , 2F , Table 1 ). The morphological differences between
P . jihueiensis
n. sp.
and
P . kihawensis
n. sp.
are discussed under the Remarks of the latter species.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 3.
Pseudonereis jihueiensis
n. sp.
; A–D, holotype (NMNS 8383-1), E–F, paratype (NMNS 8383-13): A, notochaeta, homogomph spiniger, chaetiger 12; B, supra-acicular homogomph spiniger, chaetiger 8; C, supra-acicular short-bladed heter- ogomph falciger, chaetiger 8; D, subacicular short-bladed heterogomph falciger, chaetiger 8; E, parapodial chaetae, chaetigers 29–30; F, parapodial chaetae, chaetigers 70–71. Abbreviation: SubHeF, subacicular heterogomph falciger; SupHeF, supra-acicu- lar heterogomph falciger; SupHoS, supra-acicular homogomph spiniger. Scale: A–D, 0.01 mm; E–F, 0.1 mm.

FIGURE 4.
Pseudonereis jihueiensis
n. sp.
; paratype (NMNS 8383-18), male epitoke: A, right parapodium, chaetiger 9; B, right parapodium, chaetiger 14; C, right parapodium, chaetiger 27; D, right parapodium, chaetiger 52; E, right parapodium, chaetiger 72; F, right parapodium, chaetiger 81; G, right parapodium, chaetiger 95; H, right parapodium, anterior view, chaetiger 102. Abbreviation: DCLa, dorsal cirrus lamella; NePLa, neuropodial postchaetal lamella; NeVLLo, neuropodial ventral ligule lobe; NoDLLo, notopodial dorsal ligule lobe; NoVL, notopodial ventral ligule; VCLa, ventral cirrus lamella; VCLo, ventral cirrus lobe. Scale: A–F, 0.5 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Epitokes of nereidids are known to undergo dramatic changes in the body to enable the worms to swim more effectively during swarming in the water column; the swimming abilities are enhanced in part by acquisition ad- ditional lobes on the parapodia and specialised paddle-like natatory chaetae (Bakken et al . in press). However, these two morphological modifications are not present in all epitokes of nereidids. In the present case, only additional lobes on the parapodia, but not the paddle-like natatory chaetae, were observed for both sexes of
P . jihueiensis
n. sp.
A similar case of lacking natatory chaetae in nereidids was also observed for male epitoke of
Nereis denhamensis Augener, 1913
(
Glasby et al . 2013
).
